Theability to change biological age at will would revolutionize the way humans view aging and could potentially lead to the development of new medical treatments and interventions to slow down or even reverse the aging process.
It could lead to a new era of personalized medicine, where treatments are tailored to an individual's specific biological age rather than their chronological age.
It could have a significant impact on the workforce, with older workers being able to continue working longer and younger workers being able to enter the workforce at a younger age.

It could also have implications for social and cultural norms around age and retirement, as people would no longer be limited by their biological age in terms of their ability to contribute to society.
It could also lead toability to have children at a later age, which would give women more time to focus on their careers and other pursuits before starting a family.
